TitleText: 1	Keep your eyes peeled for cosmic debris :
LeftText: 4	Stardust is a NASA space capsule
8	and landed back on Earth on January 15 , 2006 .
9	It was decided that a collaborative online review process would be used
10	to " discover " the microscopically small samples
12	The project is called Stardust @ home .
13	Unlike distributed computing projects like SETI @ home , Stardust @ home relies entirely on human intelligence .
14	Andrew Westphal is the director of Stardust @ home .
15	Wikinews interviewed him for May 's Interview of the Month
18	As always , the interview was conducted on IRC ,

LeftText: 9	It was decided that a collaborative online review process would be used
10	to " discover " the microscopically small samples
RightText: 12	The project is called Stardust @ home .
13	Unlike distributed computing projects like SETI @ home , Stardust @ home relies entirely on human intelligence .
14	Andrew Westphal is the director of Stardust @ home .
15	Wikinews interviewed him for May 's Interview of the Month
18	As always , the interview was conducted on IRC ,
21	what Stardust or Stardust @ home is .
22	Can you explain more about it for us ?
26	Stardust is a NASA Discovery mission
28	It is really two missions in one .
29	The primary science goal of the mission was to collect a sample from a known primitive solar - system body , a comet
34	This is the first US " sample return " mission since Apollo , and the first ever from beyond the moon .
36	By " sample return " of course I mean a mission
39	that this is the first " solid " sample return mission —
40	Genesis brought back a sample from the Sun almost two years ago ,
41	but Stardust is also bringing back the first solid samples from the local interstellar medium —
42	basically this is a sample of the Galaxy .
46	that there is a fantastic launch video
47	— taken from the POV of the rocket on the JPL Stardust website —
50	all the way from the launch pad , too .
53	Is the video available to the public ?
59	before can do any kind of analysis of these interstellar dust particles
67	— at least on the scale of the particle size —
68	about a tenth of a square meter .
70	We 're right now using an automated microscope
71	that we developed several years ago for nuclear astrophysics work
72	to scan the collector in the Cosmic Dust Lab in Building 31 at Johnson Space Center .
75	( Moon Rocks , Genesis chips , Meteorites , and Interplanetary Dust Particles
76	collected by U2 in the stratosphere ) .
77	The microscope collects stacks of digital images of the aerogel collectors in the array .
78	These images are sent to us
80	and convert them into a format appropriate for Stardust @ home .
81	Stardust @ home is a highly distributed project
83	that is written in html and javascript
87	volunteers can search over the collector for the tracks of the interstellar dust particles .
88	Aerogel slice removed with an ultrasonic blade ,
92	How many samples do you anticipate
93	being found during the course of the project ?
95	The short answer is that we do n't know .
96	The long answer is a bit more complicated .
98	The Galileo and Ulysses spacecraft carried dust detectors onboard
99	that Eberhard Gruen and his colleagues used
101	and them measure the flux of interstellar dust particles
103	( This is a kind of " wind " of interstellar dust ,
105	that our solar system is moving with respect to the local interstellar medium . )
106	Markus Landgraf has estimated the number of interstellar dust particles
107	that should have been captured by Stardust during two periods of the " cruise " phase of the interplanetary orbit
108	in which the spacecraft was moving with this wind .
110	that there should be around 45 particles ,
111	but this number is very uncertain
113	if it is quite different from that .
117	is that like all research , the outcome of what we are doing is highly uncertain .
122	it would n't be called " research " ,
124	How big would the samples be ?
126	that the particles will be of order a micron in size .
130	they will be looking not for the particles , but for the tracks
134	Just yesterday we switched over to a new site
135	which has a demo of the VM
137	I invite you to check it out .
138	The tracks in the demo are from submicron carbonyl iron particles
142	to accelerate dust particles to very high speeds ,
143	to simulate the interstellar dust impacts
145	And that 's on the main Stardust @ home website
